body:
yes, I want it for storage, file uploads, hashing, streaming downloads, checking things like 'raw' connections to csv files and the like, header propagation, JSON and XML validation.

Libcloud does support your own secrets, but all of the test modules are currently using the MockHttp class, which doesn't look hardly anything like the actual implementation. I've introduced `requests_mock` which allows you to introduce a http-handler as a context manager so you're only mocking out the base http call. 

This PR is about running a real end-to-end test, without having to spend $$ on a cloud provider. I hope that I can get it to work with Travis. But as a minimum it'll be part of the release process.
mergey merge
Good catch.
@Kami this is the second change to fix the issue you mentioned.
merging

@allardhoeve with regards to the comments on the hasher.

The existing library has tests for some really odd scenarios. I still don't understand why you would want to upload a generator to an S3 bucket?

I do understand why you would want to consume a buffered reader, like a `file` object, or a `StringIO` or `BytesIO` stream. That makes total sense. The existing drivers have checks in them assume that the storage base class will return a hash. Since there were 3 callbacks in the past, which implemented seperate logic for the hashing, one supported file_path. I understand that, one supported iterators (don't understand but it's existing functionality so I don't want to break back compat) and the other supported streams, but there wasn't really any testing for it.

This base class still needs significant refactoring, so far I have an account for GCP which I'm using to test file streams, but I need more integration scenarios. #970 should provide a good baseline of existing functionality and allow for better refactoring.

I hadn't noticed that you had already merged this. Guess the review isn't
need any more then :)

@tonybaloney Here's what I'm doing which still fails as of 3dd6d018:

```
from libcloud.storage.types import Provider
from libcloud.storage.providers import get_driver

GoogleStorageDriver = get_driver(Provider.GOOGLE_STORAGE)
driver = GoogleStorageDriver(key='GOOG***', secret='***')
remote_object = driver.get_object('containername', 'objectname')
print(remote_object)
stream = driver.download_object_as_stream(remote_object)
next(stream)
```
@pquentin does this fix your script?

@tonybaloney Sorry, no. I double-checked to ensure I had the code from this PR. I still get the same issue, both with my code and the minimal example from https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/923#issuecomment-271784099

@pquentin https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/973/commits/1eb58838df91ff8d9156a341b1ef560f601f7277 should fix the issue, I've been testing that script you sent me against my GCP account and it works. The unit tests are broken, but only because the mocks are missing certain properties..

@tonybaloney Awesome, it works! The only difference is that the generator yields one byte per `next()` call, while the old one was yielding byte chunks (8096 bytes is the default value I think). Not an issue for me, but I thought I would mention it.
@tonybaloney Perfect, this fixes it! I no longer see any differences between the old libcloud and the requests-based libcloud! üëè Thank you for you work and fixing those issues this quickly.

Passed. Merging.

**Fixed doc strings that were copied, but not updated to the correct parameter.**

**Description**

I fixed the doc strings of the following functions:

[ex_copy_image](http://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/stable/apidocs/libcloud.compute.drivers.html#libcloud.compute.drivers.gce.GCENodeDriver.ex_copy_image)

1. the url param annotation was being used as the type annotation

[ex_create_image](http://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/stable/apidocs/libcloud.compute.drivers.html#libcloud.compute.drivers.gce.GCENodeDriver.ex_create_image)

1. the keyword annotation was typo'd to keywork.

[ex_delete_access_config](http://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/stable/apidocs/libcloud.compute.drivers.html#libcloud.compute.drivers.gce.GCENodeDriver.ex_delete_access_config)

1. the name keyword's type annotation was copied from node.

[ex_get_image](http://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/stable/apidocs/libcloud.compute.drivers.html#libcloud.compute.drivers.gce.GCENodeDriver.ex_get_image)

1. the ex_project_list parameter's type annotation was using ',' instead of 'or' for multiple types.

[ex_get_license](http://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/stable/apidocs/libcloud.compute.drivers.html#libcloud.compute.drivers.gce.GCENodeDriver.ex_get_license)

1. There were two annotations for name when the project annotation was missing.

[ex_get_subnetwork](http://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/stable/apidocs/libcloud.compute.drivers.html#libcloud.compute.drivers.gce.GCENodeDriver.ex_get_subnetwork)

1. There were two annotations for name when the region annotation was missing.

[ex_instancegroup_list_instances](http://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/stable/apidocs/libcloud.compute.drivers.html#libcloud.compute.drivers.gce.GCENodeDriver.ex_instancegroup_list_instances)

1. The instancegroup type annotation was using double back ticks around the type instead of single ticks.

[ex_destroy_subnetwork](http://libcloud.readthedocs.io/en/stable/apidocs/libcloud.compute.drivers.html#libcloud.compute.drivers.gce.GCENodeDriver.ex_destroy_subnetwork)

1. There were two annotations for name when the region annotation was missing.

**Status**
done, ready for review

I understand that introducing multiprocessing is a big change for libcloud, however it is a no go if you want list_nodes to return soon and have a big number of projects. This has worked without problems for us on mist.io for Azure, vCloud and packet.net . Happy to provide more info

@tonybaloney let me confirm with the Outscale fellows. I hope to have more information this week. Thanks!

@Kami keen for your thoughts. One of the biggest bits of feedback with the requests re-implementation was why didn't we just go straight to aiohttp. It would have wrecked the backward compat and pretty much every user. So I'm seeking a common ground that doesn't mean having a base class with 2x as many methods (async_list_nodes and list_nodes). 

This way replaces `list_nodes` and would other methods, with an awaitable coroutine. It _could_ also swap out requests with aiohttp in the underlying connection attribute for the duration of the context session.

I like that approach :+1: 

One option would also be to have async version of each driver (e.g. `EC2AsyncNodeDriver` / `AsyncEC2NodeDriver`) or simply `libcloud.compute.drivers.async.EC2NodeDriver`. User would then select which one to use when using `get_driver` factory method.

This way user wouldn't need to wrap the whole code or multiple operations in the context manager.

Having said that, I do think that backward compatibility is very important and as you have said this limits some of the options which are available to us.

On a related note - would also be good to check what other Python HTTP libraries which support both, sync and async implementations do (and maybe take some inspiration from that).

We also had some debate about this in the past, maybe also worth digging out the mailing list thread and see if we can salvage some ideas from there.

While this is a good start, you're still blocking the loop because your transport still isn't async.
And just to make sure, you know you're returning a future which needs to be `await`'ed right?

For my own projects I tend to choose `asyncio` but if you still want to support py2, either you have 2 versions of each driver, py2 sync(threadpool for async?), py3 async or sync, or, you choose something like tornado which still works with py2 and py3.
The drawback is that you're no longer using native coroutines.

I think trying to add async support to libcloud is a worthwile goal. Unfortunately, you did not really accomplish much here. On the API side, to use the async version of libcloud, users will still need to use the `await` keyword, so avoiding users to write `list_nodes_async` (or something) is not a huge win. On the internal side, [the world is still divided in two](http://journal.stuffwithstuff.com/2015/02/01/what-color-is-your-function/) because you *still* have two versions of `list_nodes`.

The real problem now is: how do you make this manageable internally in libcloud? If you look at the call tree of a method like "list_nodes", what it's going to do is to make network calls around leaves of the call tree. Each such call has to be in an async function to avoid blocking the event loop, and each caller of those functions has to be an async function too! Everything is being tainted. [You wanted a banana but what you got was a gorilla holding the banana and the entire jungle](https://www.johndcook.com/blog/2011/07/19/you-wanted-banana/). The very nature of libcloud makes this a real challenge. Try to get an async list_nodes to work without changing any other functions, and look at all the code you had to modify/copy paste. How do you keep the two versions in sync?

One option is to use the approach of https://github.com/njsmith/h11 or https://effect.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html which totally decouples the I/O from the business logic, which allows to use different wrappers. But that basically requires rewriting libcloud, introducing lots of bugs.

Another one is to write fully async code and provide sync wrappers. This is probably not a good idea because the library now needs to introduce its own event loop and it's not the away asyncio is supposed to work in Python. There are probably [other, more subtle concerns](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/pfxteam/2012/04/13/should-i-expose-synchronous-wrappers-for-asynchronous-methods/) (C# had a lot more time to think about this.) And I'm not even talking about Python 2 support, which does not have an usable event loop. (Trollius is not maintained and should not be used right now.)

See this requests issue for more discussions about this (https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests/issues/1390). No wonder no popular library I know of currently offers async/sync support. It's much easier to actually write two different libraries. But that's probably not a good idea for libcloud to divide the eyeballs even more.

I'll try and get those points in order,

1. the transport isn't async - correct. I'm going to raise a few pull requests with different design patterns and ask the community to discuss pro's and con's. We'll see the benefits and performance gains from the 2nd pattern. I don't completely believe the transport needs to be a coroutine 

2. "you know you're returning a future", yes- that was kind of the point, the idea here is that the user can build a coroutine which runs a sequence of steps against the API and then wait for the event loop to close out.

3. On the API side, to use the async version of libcloud, users will still need to use the await keyword- exactly. I work on another C# library, it's common practice now for a C#.NET package to expose all Async methods as awaitable to give the caller control over which Task API to use, they can just await it, then can use a Thread pool, etc. etc.

All the logic inside the drivers is about manipulating request and response dictionaries, authenticating APIs and sometimes doing list comprehensions and model projections, whether the call to the underlying API is the coroutine or the method itself is a coroutine won't make a difference since the method will still need to await the response. 

In the `requests-futures` example, I want to copy a similar principle but apply it in a context manager, the context manager in this PR changes a NodeDrivers core methods to become coroutine's.

```python
from requests_futures.sessions import FuturesSession

session = FuturesSession()
# first request is started in background
future_one = session.get('http://httpbin.org/get')
# second requests is started immediately
future_two = session.get('http://httpbin.org/get?foo=bar')
# wait for the first request to complete, if it hasn't already
response_one = future_one.result()
print('response one status: {0}'.format(response_one.status_code))
print(response_one.content)
# wait for the second request to complete, if it hasn't already
response_two = future_two.result()
print('response two status: {0}'.format(response_two.status_code))
print(response_two.content)
```
It would make sense to write down some use cases and demonstrate them using each design pattern. I'll work on that.

Taking inspiration from a [gist using storage you posted in January](https://gist.github.com/tonybaloney/e7159fbe72b81decce0395ceb87aa358), I would like to be able to do things like:

```
GoogleStorageDriver = get_driver(Provider.GOOGLE_STORAGE)
driver = await GoogleStorageDriver(key='GOOG***', secret='****')

tasks = []
async for container in driver.list_containers():
    async for object in driver.list_container_objects(containers[0]):
        tasks.append(asyncio.ensure_future(do_stuff_with_object(object))
await asyncio.gather(*tasks)
```

If the event loop was blocked by synchronous transport, then this code would be just as slow as synchronous code. With async transport, then the do_stuff_with_object calls would be done in parallel. The other calls (especially the async fors) would still be sequential, but would free the event loop to allow other unrelated code to run concurrently.

@Kami @s0undt3ch @pquentin option 2: 
https://github.com/apache/libcloud/pull/1027

Ideally here, the driver methods should not need to change, the async methods should patch out calls to `self.connection.request` with `self.connection.request_async`. 
Also I haven't exposed the ability to provide the event loop with the driver constructor, but this would be simple to achieve.

This looks good. Thanks for the detailed sketch! üëç 

However, I'm worried about needing to reimplement every driver method as async. You're saying the drivers methods should not need to change. But even if `self.connection.request` in monkeypatched to be made async, you still need `await` to call it, which does not work without modifying `iterate_containers`, right? Am I missing something?

@tonybaloney to make things clear, I'm not saying I don't want to use an async context manager. I'm just saying I'd like to be able to use await and asyncio.ensure_future() with an async transport. As an user, the details of the API itself are somewhat irrelevant.
